verb.description: Have as belonging to one; own.
examples: I do not possess a television set

verb.description: (of a demon or spirit, especially an evil one) have complete power over (someone) and be manifested through their speech or actions.
examples: she was possessed by the Devil

verb.description: Maintain (oneself or one's mind or soul) in a state or condition of patience or quiet.
examples: I tried to possess my soul in patience and to forget how hungry I was

phrases: what possessed you to come here?
What possessed you to train for a marathon at the North Pole, one of the coldest, most desolate places on Earth?
What possessed you to take this test? I mean, seriously...
Which brings me back to that question: "What possessed you to do that to your hair?"
origin: Late Middle English: from Old French possesser, from Latin possess- occupied, held, from the verb possidere, from potis able, capable + sedere sit.
